Tuesday, Sept. 14, 1926.
Called on Mr. Shaw,
South San Francisco Land and Improve-
ment Company, Merchants Exchange Building.
Suggested that the limit to be paid by the City for the
100 acres involved in site No. 2 would be
$260,000.00, provided that
the land be brought to an elevation of plus 10 feet by the present
owner; that in addition, the land Company
would have to include
a right of way for a spur track from the Belt Railroad into the
proposed aeroplane site.
Mr. Shaw stated that if we submitted the offer it would
be forwarded to his company, but that he would not recommend its
acceptance.

NORBS CH
AIRPORT
Priday, Sept. 17, 1926.
At the request of the Chamber of Connerce and suggested
by the Supervisors attending the luncheon to Assistant Secretary
the Navy Marner, I met Mr.
arner and the officens o the
Twelfth Naval Division at Harrison and Spear Streets at 2:30 o'clock.
We left about 3:00 o'clock and visited the South San Francisco site
and millbrae site.
Did not visit the San late site,
98 14 was not
suitable for hydroplanes. Returned to San Prancisco at 4:45 o'clock
The Assistant Secretary expressed the opinion that the
site at South San Prancisco was not admirably adapted for hydro-
pLanes as the hydroplane would probably have to taxi at some three
mes ocrore a coud start to rise.
Depth of water is needed for
hydroplanes, according to the Assistant Secretary, in order to enable
boats to deliver supplies direct to the hydroplanes.
Te also visited the Milbrae site and the Assistant
Secretary said that it appeared to him that this was a much better
Salver
Not being familiar with the direction of the winds at all
times he could not state whether it was ideal or not.
He also asked
concerning drainage on both sites and whether during the winter
SONS the land would be waterlogged.
He also made the statement
that if it were a question of securing a field not suitable for
hydroplanes but absolutely clear of fog, that he would select that
field rather than take a fleld suitable for hydroplanes that had
fog at times.
Guersey of the Chamber of Commerce accompanied the
party;
also Rear-Admiral Thomas Tashington, Commandant of the District,
Rear-Admiral Peeples, of the supply corps,
Lieutenant Commander B.
Go
Leighton,
the assistant
Foy.
